Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5H8G-90V1-DXH2-652T-00000-00Q3 2015 Ingram Micro Inc Earnings Call - Final2015-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:43ZLexisNexis102915a5835613.713Q3 2015 Ingram Micro IncEarnings Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Damon Wright

Ingram Micro- Executive Director, IR

* Bill Humes

Ingram Micro- CFO

* Alain Monie

Ingram Micro- CEO

* Paul Read

Ingram Micro- President, COO

Conference Call Participants

* Brian Alexander

Raymond James & Associates, Inc.- Analyst

* Matt Sheerin

Stifel Nicolaus - Analyst

* Ananda Baruah

Brean Capital, LLC - Analyst

* Jim Suva

Citigroup - Analyst

* Louis Miscioscia

CLSA Limited - Analyst

* David Rold

Needham & Co. - Analyst

* Osten Bernardez

Cross Research - Analyst

* Keith Housum

Northcoast Research - Analyst

Presentation

OPERATOR: Greetings and welcome to the Ingram Micro's third quarter 2015 earnings call. At this time, all participant are in a listen-only mode. A brief question-and-answer session will follow the formal presentation. (Operator Instructions). As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Damon Wright, Executive Director of IR. Thank you. You may begin.

DAMON WRIGHT, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, IR, INGRAM MICRO: Thank you and good afternoon. Joining me today are Alain Monie, our CEO and Bill Humes, our CFO. Paul Read, our President and COO is joining us from the road. Bill and Alain will make remarks after which the call will be open for a question-and-answer session. We have also prepared presentation slides to highlight key aspects of our financial performance which can be found with today's news release in the investor relation section of Ingram Micro's website.

During today's discussion, we'll make statements that are forward-looking including providing our financial outlook related to the 2015 fourth quarter. These forward-looking statements and all other statements made on this call that are not historical facts are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties. These statements are forward looking and actual results may differ materially.

Please refer to today's news release and the documents filed with the Securities & Exchange Commission, specifically the risk factors listed in item 1a of our latest form 10-k for more information on the risks that could cause actual results to differ materially. Throughout this call, we'll refer to non-GAAP financial measures. Today's earnings release and the related current report describe the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting and present the reconciliation between the two for the periods reported in the release.

Please also see the Investor Section of our website for our slide deck that includes additional information, disclosed under SEC Regulation G. This conference call is the property of Ingram Microand may not be recorded or rebroadcast without specific written permission from the Company.

I would now like to turn the call over to Bill. Bill?

BILL HUMES, CFO, INGRAM MICRO: Thank you, Damon. Good afternoon, everyone. We delivered another quarter of great execution, highlighted by a 21% increase in earnings per share on a currency neutral basis. We continued to drive efficiencies across our core business and benefit for prior investments in a faster growing, higher margin areas. We are executing on our strategy which combined with a focus on working capital, helped generate $340 million in operating cash flow, bringing our year-to-date cash generation from operations to $965 million.

Revenue for the second quarter was $10.5 billion. Within our guidance range and representing an increase of 2% on a currency neutral basis. Excluding the negative impact related to exiting portions of our North American Mobility distribution business, as discussed last quarter, worldwide revenue was up approximately 5% on a currency neutral basis.

The strengthening of the US dollar had an 8% negative impact on revenues in US dollar terms. Our recent acquisitions contributed two percentage points of growth. Gross margin was 6.31%, a 56 basis point improvement over last year. The acquisition of mobility services ANOVO contributed 30 basis points of the improvement and the remaining increase was driven by the combination of stronger value sales across all regions and lower North American mobility distribution sales.

Non-GAAP operating margin was 1.6% with the highest for our third quarter in more than a decade, increasing 17 basis points over last year due primarily to gross margin improvement and strong operating leverage in our core business across most countries. Non-GAAP interest and other expense of $28 million was up $4.5 million over the 2014 third quarter. Resulting from interest on our December 2014 bond offering and higher foreign exchange costs related to volatility in global currencies.

Non-GAAP EPS at $0.67 was near the high end of our guidance range, an increase of 21% on a currency neutral basis. Translation of foreign currencies had an $0.08 negative impact when compared to last year. $0.02 greater than our expectations entering the quarter.

Now, looking at some regional details, North America revenue of $4.5 billion was down 13% in US dollars and down 11% on a currency neutral basis. Continued strength in data center and networking infrastructure particularly for SMB and direct marketers was more than offset by lower mobility distribution as we exited portions of the business that did not meet our profitability objectives. Additionally, demand for PCs and tablets was soft in the region, especially when compared to robust PC growth last year.

Our focus on value was rewarded as North America delivered a non-GAAP operating margin of 2.48% up 42 basis points versus last year. North America had good contribution from specialty and advanced solutions and mobility life-cycle service also added strong profitability resulting from higher volumes in forward and reverse logistics and repairs. Europe revenue $2.9 billion was up 8% on a currency neutral basis. But down 8% in US dollars. Local currency revenue strength was driven by strong iPhone demand and solid sales of advance and specialty solutions.

Additionally, the acquisition of ANOVO added two percentage points of growth. Demand in Germany, the largest regional contributor, improved in Q3 with strength from corporate resalers in categories including networking, data capture point of sale and mobility. France and the UK also contributed strong growth and Spain delivered double digit growth supported by an uptick to advanced solution sales in both countries and strong mobility sales in Italy.

Non-GAAP operating margin was 62 basis points. Our European technology solutions business continues to deliver year-over-year improvement with expanding growth in operating margins. However this progress was diluted by our efforts to build out our higher margin strategic businesses including in mobility and to expand our Cloud marketplace throughout the region. Asia Pacific continues to be a standout performer with revenues of $2.5 billion representing an increase of 16% on a currency neutral basis and 6% in US dollars.

Our acquisitions in Turkey and Saudi Arabia contributed approximately five percentage points of growth. Non-GAAP operating margin of 1.61% was up year-over-year by 22 basis points. Supported by solid demand for higher margin solutions and our recent value focused acquisitions. The region experienced particular strength in infrastructure software, unified communications and virtualization offerings. Strong growth and profitability in India was bolstered by robust demand across most product lines, especially in enterprise end markets.

Australia continues to post double digit growth above the region's average and China delivered another quarter of solid growth due to strong mobility sales and the addition of new vendor lines. Our Middle East business contributed strong profitability benefiting from a strict value focus and contributions from recent acquisitions. Latin America led all regions in growth with revenue of $582 million increasing 11% in US dollars and 32% on a currency neutral base.

The addition of acquired distribution businesses in Peru and Chile, along with our ANOVO business in the regions, contributed approximately 11 percentage points of growth. Our largest countries in the region, Mexico and Brazil, each had a robust double digit growth with strength broadly. Profitability in Latin America was solid with non-GAAP operating margin of 1.59%.

Turning to other financial highlights in the quarter, HP represented 14%. Apple, 12%. And Cisco, 10% of total sales in Q3. CapEx for the quarter was $42 million and depreciation was $23 million. Non-GAAP return on invested capital was 10.6%, above our weighted average cost to capitol by more than 250 basis points.

At quarter end, our cash balance was nearly $1 billion and net debt totaled $280 million. Working capital days are 25. A two-day sequential improvement which resulted from progress in influencing our working capital improvement program. This improvement helped generate $340 million operating cash flows for the quarter bringing year-to-date operating cash flow to $965 million.

I'll now turn the call over to Alain.

ALAIN MONIE, CEO, INGRAM MICRO: Thanks, Bill. We had a great third quarter with very solid execution resulting in continued operating margin expansion, robust EPS growth and excellent cash flow generation. We delivered good revenue growth across key areas of our business with broad-based demand globally, for high value specialty and advanced solutions. Particularly for data center and network infrastructure deployments.

We're generating significant momentum in this important category which is contributing to strong and expanding growth and operating margins. Our performance has established Ingram as one of the leading technology solution providers in this market. In addition to green field investments to build the capabilities and expertise required to secure new height value vendor authorizations, we have also continued to strengthen our position with vendor partners and customers through acquisitions.

Just last week, we announced our intention to acquire Grupo ACAO, another leading provider of critical value add IT solutions in Latin America. ACAO's key vendor portfolio includes Oracle, IBM, Red Hat, EMC and VMware, to name a few. We expect to realize meaningful vendor and customer cross setting opportunities in the countries we share. As there is very little overlap and together we will have a significantly expanded portfolio of high value offerings.

Upon close, this acquisition will help us continue to drive margin expansion and it is expected to contribute approximately $0.04 to non-GAAP earnings in 2016. We also continued to strengthen our relationships with core vendor partners to help meet their requirements on a global basis. For example, Dell is strategically relying on Ingram as a key partner throughout the world and in Q3, granted a distribution access to selling to its important federal market.

In mobility, our position at the center of the mobility life cycle ecosystem is a strong differentiator. Solid profitability is being driven by robust services performance particularly in North America as we expand our business with existing partners such as T-Mobile and TracFone. Our six-month-old acquisition of life cycle services ANOVO is also performing well in Europe and Ingram's global infrastructure is providing opportunities to leverage this business across new markets.

Additionally, our role as a key distribution partner for top handset OEMs is driving strong growth internationally. Our Cloud business continues to grow over 100% year-over-year on a currency neutral basis and the global expansion of our automated Cloud marketplace is producing strong demand for Ingram's Cloud offerings. We're rapidly becoming a go-to partner for leading Cloud innovators as they recognize the power and ease of views of our proprietary automation platform and increasingly rely on Ingram Microto drive widespread adoption of their solutions, especially in the SMB space.

As an example, Microsoft has tapped Ingram to play a critical role in business model transformation as we were among the first to be named a key partner in the Microsoft Cloud solution provider for CSP program worldwide. During the quarter, we had very strong Cloud revenue growth in newly entered countries and expect to benefit in Q4 from expansion into India, Singapore and Malaysia which now gives us a presence in 16 countries. Our Cloud business remains an area of investment for Ingram and it is important for us to continue to broaden our services portfolio, global footprint and leverage what we believe is superior technology and first move our advantage to capture market share.

To borrow from Satya Nadella comments last week, to be a worldwide Cloud player, global scale is a must. Commerce and fulfillment solutions continues to grow at double digit rates supported by recent international wins. Earlier this month, we announced our intention to acquire DOCDATA, one of the leading European providers of order fulfillment, returns logistics and online payment services. Similar to our established business in North America, DOCDATA provides critical commerce solutions to major retailers, brands and promising start-ups.

While we have been gaining traction in the region on a green field basis, DOCDATA is a well-respected and highly recognized brand in Europe. And this addition is expected to immediately establish Ingram Microas a significant Ecommerce logistics player in the region, providing access to business and request for proposals for which we previously had not been considered. Upon close, we expect the acquisition to contribute immediately to earnings and we're confident that we'll be able to leverage Ingram's presence and strength to accelerate additional growth and profitability in this business.

In addition to our strong execution, we're delivering on our commitment to returning capital to shareholders. In September, we made our first dividend payment and during the third quarter, we repurchased 6.4 million shares for a total cost of $161 million. Since we re-initiated our share repurchase program in May of this year, we have repurchased a little more than eight million shares for a total cost of $206 million.

As announced in our press release this afternoon, our next dividend will be paid on November 24 to stockholders of record on November 10. For Q4, we'll continue to see stable markets globally and we expect demand for higher value solutions to continue to outpace average IT Growth rates. In our core business we expect SMB to remain healthy broadly.

For our fourth quarter, we expect continued strong operating leverage and further improvement in operating margin. While we expect revenues to show historic sequential seasonal growth in the mid to high teens, we're facing difficult comparisons versus last year. Foreign exchange is expected to be at least a 6% headwind or headwind of approximately $800 million in Q4. And as we highlighted last year, our 2014 fourth quarter performance was aided by the addition of our 14th week which added approximately $850 million.

Also as previously disclosed, we expected approximately $400 million in lower North American mobility distribution revenues. Excluding these impacts, the midpoint of our Q4 revenue guidance reflects expectations for approximately 3% growth over last year. For Q4 this year, we expect revenue to be between $12 billion and $12.6 billion.

Non-GAAP earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $1 to $1.07. Which reflects a negative impact related to currency movement of $0.10 when compared to last year. And reflects an increase of 12% to 19% over the 2014 fourth quarter on a currency neutral basis. Additionally, we now expect to generate more than $1 billion in cash flow from operations for the 2015 full year, up significantly from earlier expectations of $700 million even as we deploy capital to support sequential revenue growth in our seasonally strongest fourth quarter.

In conclusion, we're executing well. Margin expansion is being driven by growing contribution from higher value businesses combined with operating leverage. Strong cash flow generation is also resulting from our working capital improvement programs. And we're delivering on our balance capital allocation strategy to continue to grow the business in important strategic areas while at the same time returning value to shareholders.

I would like to open the call to your questions now.

Questions and Answers

OPERATOR: Thank you. (Operator Instructions). One moment while we poll for questions. Thank you. Our first question comes from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James. Please proceed.

BRIAN ALEXANDER, ANALYST, RAYMOND JAMES & ASSOCIATES, INC.: Maybe start by talking about Europe and the demand environment given some comments by some of your peer distributors and competitors that -- and even your vendors that Europe remains strong. And i know you were up on constant currency. So if you could talk about demand in Europe.

And then related to that, it looks like margins in Europe were flat year-over-year, despite growth in constant currency and despite the inclusion of ANOVO. How should we think about European operating margins as you look forward and you get through this restructuring program which I know a lot of that is aimed at Europe. Are we still thinking 150 basis points of margin is possible next year? Thanks.

ALAIN MONIE: Yes, Hi Brian. This is Alain. I'll pass it on to Paul for some additional color. But let me start with the demand question. We've seen in Europe, pretty healthy demand in Germany, especially for us on the corporate resellers front. But at the same time, the SMB customer base size has also been pretty stable. And I would say strong as well. In addition to that, we had pretty strong iPhone sales across the region.

And as far as countries, I would add in addition to Germany, France, Italy, Spain, were very strong and to a certain extent, UK as well. So yes, we confirm that in local currencies we're seeing fairly stable if not strong demand in Europe.

Now, as to your question on margins, that are flat, this is a combination of a couple of things. One is we are seeing good leverage and good growth on our operating margins in our technology solutions business. But at the same time -- and that also was aided by ANOVO -- but at the same time, we keep investing particularly in mobility and in Cloud in order to make sure that we position ourselves well for 2016.

So if you combine that with our cost savings program which kick in in Europe a little later than the rest of the world which means it will be mostly fully in 2016, we're still aiming at exiting 2016 with 150 basis points or close to. Paul, you want to add anything to this?

PAUL READ, PRESIDENT, COO, INGRAM MICRO: I think you captured it Alain. We've also -- we struggle to -- the early part of this year with the lack of leverage coming out of some of the PC sales. Through the Q3 quarter and continuing through Q4, there is more sell through of the PCs into the channels. So some of the inventory has been relieved. So that's helped with leverage as well.

As Alain said, it will balancing out the mix of the business invested in the more higher value businesses whether it's acquisition or organically and I think that will come through in Q -- so in 2016 as well as with the cost reductions, we're still keeping our mind set on 150 basis points.

ALAIN MONIE: And Brian, you can also count on the data acquisition which will be hopefully fully impacting our 2016 numbers in Europe.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: And Alain, the 150 was annualized, not a Q4 target.

ALAIN MONIE: We're trying to annualize it. But it will happen more toward the end of the year than the beginning, obviously given how we enter the 2016 year.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: Right. Okay. I just wanted to make sure that wasn't a quarterly number. Then my follow-up, so on the 2016 earnings outlook, originally you gave a range of $3.40 to $3.70. That was at your 2014 analyst meeting. A lot has changed since then. The currency headwind is even greater now than it was a quarter ago when you said roughly $0.20 headwind to that range. So I just wanted to kind of level set and see where we're at for next year.

Are we down to $3.15 to $3.45 given the currency headwind or are we higher than that because of the acquisitions? Maybe if you could just kind of help frame next year relative to your original outlook and just kind of highlight at a very high level some of the major puts and takes to the outlook you gave last year.

BILL HUMES: Brian, it's Bill. Overall a couple of quarters ago, we had already communicated with the expected impact on foreign exchange back then that we did lower the targets to $3.20 to $3.50 per share. Now currencies have continued to get a little bit weaker since then and had a bigger impact even on 2015 than we originally anticipated and even when we anticipated the impact on Q3.

That being said, we're not going to adjust the 2016 numbers even further from them at this point. Foreign exchange is a moving target. And we'll re-evaluate the currencies as we close the year and get into 2016.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: Okay. Thank you.

BILL HUMES: Sure.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Matt Sheerin from Stifel. Please proceed.

MATT SHEERIN, ANALYST, STIFEL NICOLAUS: Yes, thanks. Just following up on Brian's question, it sounds like you're still targeting that $3.30 midpoint EPS, right?

BILL HUMES: Right.

MATT SHEERIN: Okay. And on the North America business related to the Verizon dealer program, where are we in terms of the revenue flowing out is there more to go this quarter? And is that it? And how, two quarters, or basically one full quarter into your new agreements and as you get into the busy season where you're going to have, obviously, a lot more volumes, how satisfied are you with the contracts and feedback you're getting from your customers there in terms of how the relationships are going?

ALAIN MONIE: We're satisfied with the new environment, what I would call new contractual terms as well as the mix of services and distribution, mix of customers. We believe that we're now in a good position to have that business contribute in a way that is satisfactory for us. So I would say Q4 will be stable, new environment for us and we believe that we've done most of the correction course, if you will, in Q3. But, Bill do you have any --

BILL HUMES: Yes, overall in Q3, there was an impact obviously. As effective at the beginning of the quarter, we did exit certain lines of that business. So we were down a little bit over $300 million year-over-year in the revenues. That's a big impact of what you see in the North American revenue growth rates. Now that amount will generally grow because it is a fourth quarter centric business. But we still expect it to be down, as Alain had mentioned earlier, about $400 million on a year-over-year basis but at better profitability and less capital usage levels.

MATT SHEERIN: Okay. And then just back to Europe and the margins and the costs that are coming out there. I understand how that flows through. But what about investments that those incremental investments you're making in Cloud, supply chain, et cetera. Are they starting to sort of play out so that you'll begin to get that leverage in the model?

ALAIN MONIE: I would say, Matt, yes, on the supply chain and e-commerce solutions, particularly as we add DOCDATA, which is the recent acquisition. But not only that, we also had pretty good organic wins on new contracts, especially in the UK, and those are going to be contributing. On the Cloud, we're still in investment mode because we need to get all the countries. And as you know, the complexity of Europe as far as having data being residing in country versus outside of the country, it gets a little more complicated. But we are lighting up several countries next year in order to really have our cloud offering available as broadly as possible.

MATT SHEERIN: Got it. Okay. All right. Thanks, guys.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Ananda Baruah with Brean Capital. Please proceed.

ANANDA BARUAH, ANALYST, BREAN CAPITAL, LLC: Hey, guys. Thanks for taking the questions. Appreciate it. I guess just a few from me. In North America, with regards to the portions of the business that you said you're exiting, how much of that -- not quantified, but does that -- well, let me ask you this way, does that include both the Verizon business as well as ongoing PC business that you're walking away from?

ALAIN MONIE: It is mainly and mostly, is around what we call the Verizon ecosystem. That's where most of it has been exiting. On the PC side, I wouldn't call it the exiting business, I would be qualifying that much more as being selective on which deals we take and which we don't. And that by the way has happened in Q3, which is part of the PC's negative impact, which was driven, not only by the market itself, but also by our own decisions to take or not take those business. But in Q4, it's mostly around the so called Verizon business.

ANANDA BARUAH: That's really helpful. Thanks, Alain. And on the PC dynamic, you find that it's -- you're having to become increasingly selective or, I mean, I know that we've sort of worked into that dynamic over the last couple few years. Do you feel like you're at sort of a normalized practice of having to be selective, or do you find yourself having to be increasingly selective still?

ALAIN MONIE: Paul, would you like to take this? You're on mute.

PAUL READ: Yes, Ananda, hello. Sorry.

ANANDA BARUAH: Yes.

PAUL READ: It is a difficult comp, as you know, year-over-year for PCs with the refresh last year. But I wouldn't describe the environment as being increasingly more selective, we've always been selective. And there is softness that we saw in the market out there anyway throughout the quarter and we expect that to continue into Q4, and we will continue to be selective, it's no doubt. If it doesn't have the returns that we need, then we will choose to pass on some of those larger, higher volume deals that come our way.

ANANDA BARUAH: And how do you guys feel about the channel inventory levels of notebooks now, PCs?

PAUL READ: It certainly eased definitely in Europe in Q3 with a lot of vendor support on pricing, some of -- a lot of the inventory had moved through. So some stabilizing there of the situation, which was good for us and that's why you saw some leverage there with Europe, and I think that will continue into Q4 as well. We haven't yet seen any real pickup from Windows 10. I'm sure we'll see some of that next year, but so far it's really not been notable.

ANANDA BARUAH: Thanks. And just the last one from me, Bill. What -- I think you mentioned in the press release there was a $0.02 incremental headwind to EPS from the time you gave September Q guidance, what's the right way to think about what the December Q impact is from the beginning of the September Q, without trying to make it too complicated? And so really what I'm asking is, when we sort of look at where street numbers, where for December Q going into tonight's call, what would be that incremental impact from when you gave the September Q guidance, is it a little bit greater than the $0.02 for December Q?

BILL HUMES: Yes. I mean, overall, we've disclosed that we expect the impacts on a year-over-year basis to be about $0.10. I mean what it would have been, I guess or expected, when if we were given fourth quarter guidance at the beginning of Q3 in our earnings release for Q2. I mean, it's obviously a little bit larger, but probably in that same ballpark of maybe $0.02 to $0.03 larger overall than what we originally thought.

ANANDA BARUAH: Got it. That's helpful. Okay, guys. Thanks a lot.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Jim Suva with Citi. Please proceed.

JIM SUVA, ANALYST, CITIGROUP: Thank you, and congratulations on your results. I have two questions, one on the mobility side, and the other on PCs. First, on mobility, in the past few months, there's been a lot of changes about what the carriers and Apple is doing, specifically with changes to duration of contracts, leasings, get a new phone every year type of programs. Is that having an impact to the Company or should it, like will you have to do more now with second hand used phones, or do you see people potentially going to the OEM Apple directly as opposed to some of the retail shops? How should we just think about that? It's just not Apple, it's also some of the others doing shorter duration. Therefore people are turning in their phones faster. I don't know maybe that actually helps you, or do you then have to find a second hand market for the used phones?

And then, my question on the PCs is if you compare PCs to earlier in the year, or maybe versus seasonality of what is expected for normal seasonality, have PCs and the inventory demand gotten worse, or in line with seasonality or improved, or how should we think about that? Because I believe that first half of the year was significantly lower than expected. Now, in the second half, seasonality will help, but I'm wondering if it's -- I know it's still challenged, but has it actually gotten worse or a little bit better? Thank you.

ALAIN MONIE: Hey, Jim, I'll -- this is the Alain. I'll take the first question on mobility, I'll pass it on to Paul for the PCs question. On the mobility front, you're correct that there are a number of changes out there and it's true in different countries, not only here in the US on what the carriers are doing, what they're not doing anymore, the things that Apple now is taking. I would say, there are two main elements of potential impact to us and, I'd say, impact being positive.

The first one is that, as there is more and more distribution and open market availability of product, that plays into one of our strengths being extremely good there, not only in distributing those products, but also attaching services around it. On the other hand, we are also very strong with the services to the carriers. So we are on both ends of those two different strategies and when it shifts from one to the other, we benefit in both ends. So there is a transfer of opportunity for us.

However, on the second and, you alluded to that, the fact that some of these devices now are going to turn more rapidly, really play into our repair services where we have really well established capabilities now and authorizations from the major OEMs. So the more of these devices turn, the better it is for us, the more we have a chance to capture the value and the remarketing of those devices, which has been a growing business for us, can be called a regeneration or can be called trade-ins. We are in all these markets. So it is -- if anything, it will be a favorable impact to us. Paul, you want to answer the question on PCs?

PAUL READ: Yes, Alain. So, Jim, I think you'd have to look back to last year. We had a very strong second half around the globe on PCs, the first half with the refresh. So I think if you look at seasonality or sequentially, it was very strong last year. So it's fair to say that this year it's a lot softer than last year seasonality or sequentially, whatever way you look at it. There are some pockets of growth, Asia-Pac, Latin America, we actually have had growth. But I've mentioned North America was soft, and I think that'll be soft in Q4 as well, so down seasonality, down sequentially. And Europe was flat, and the flatness really was a lot of support from vendors to sell-through some aged inventory. And that's how we see Q4 going. So it's a little bit of a mix picture, but definitely I think the comment would be down seasonally.

JIM SUVA: Thank you for your details.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Lou Miscioscia with CLSA. Please proceed.

LOUIS MISCIOSCIA, ANALYST, CLSA LIMITED: Okay. Thank you. Hey, Paul, could you just expand on that last comment when you said down seasonally. And I guess, where I'm coming from, some -- the very big tech companies, maybe you don't do. But you do some of the data center products, did talk about pauses, whether EMC, IBM, Oracle, VMware and others. So just wondering if some of the areas seem reasonably decent for you all. So I was just a bit surprised maybe it's not weaker. So just expand on the comment, please.

PAUL READ: Yes, certainly. Well, I was just trying to explain that from a PC perspective, last year was very strong for us, first half versus second half, so therefore seasonally high in Q3, Q4. That jump is certainly not as great this year from first half to second half. US has definitely slowed down from what we sell, of course, and Europe is flattened out, and there's pockets of growth in Asia. I think you can break it down also that on desktops and notebooks, it was down for us in the US. Europe, desktops are actually up and notebooks were down for us. So it's kind of flat overall. And then in both categories, Asia-Pac and Latin America, were both up.

And so what we're seeing is a selling through of some older inventory and not a great pickup seasonally on the Windows 10 or other things that could be driving it. Now, we are seeing strength in tablets, for example, and other products like that, which is driving some demand for us. But we've said no comments. Networking -- network infrastructure and data center software virtualization, all these other products, higher value solutions for us, are growing very, very well, and that's where a lot of our margin accretion is coming from. And that's some investments that we've been making over the last few years that seem to be paying off with some of our major vendors.

LOUIS MISCIOSCIA: Okay. Last quarter, I think you talked about some modest growth in China. Maybe if you can just tell us what's going on there, given it seems like the economy is slowing?

PAUL READ: Yes. We've benefited, we've had mid-single-digit growth in a couple of quarters and we've benefited really from some new products entering the market on the phone side and other consumer products as well. So I think the team there's doing a really good job capturing some market share. Q4 won't be as great, I don't think, although, we still see some growth. But we had a good Q3 and a good Q2. So I think they're executing pretty well at that.

LOUIS MISCIOSCIA: And maybe the last question would be on the Cloud, you talked about it a little bit. Any chance that we could either get it sized, or at some point get it sized?

PAUL READ: Sizing is required. I'll leave that to Alain.

ALAIN MONIE: Yes. We're really in the mode of investing and deploying our Cloud offerings there. Clearly, when we have more detailed data that we can share, we would certainly do that. I wouldn't expect us to be able to share Cloud details probably until the end of next year, but without a commencement yet.

LOUIS MISCIOSCIA: Okay. Thanks, guys. Good luck on the rest of the year.

ALAIN MONIE: Thank you.

BILL HUMES: Thank you.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of David Rold with Needham & Co. Please proceed.

DAVID ROLD, ANALYST, NEEDHAM & CO.: Hi. Thank you. Just a quick one on the cash flow. Was the improvement just at the mobility working capital freeing up, or was there another component there?

BILL HUMES: No, I don't know. If you look at -- this is Bill by the way, David. But the increase in the cash flow produced in Q3 really of $340 million, really comes mostly from a sequential working capital day improvement of a little over two days, the rest comes from the overall operating income after tax production. So, overall, it's a working capital day improvement. Now, we do have a very significant by-country working capital reduction or improvement program around the globe and that's what we're driving very hard. So we do expect to continue to drive working capital days going forward down to an improved level

DAVID ROLD: Okay, great. Thank you.

BILL HUMES: Sure.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our next question comes from the line of Osten Bernardez with Cross Research. Please proceed.

OSTEN BERNARDEZ, ANALYST, CROSS RESEARCH: Hi. Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my questions. Real quickly, I was just wondering with respect to the dynamics of your mobility business, you commented that you're expecting that, I guess, the margin profile to remain relatively stable, is my understanding for the fourth quarter. But given sort of the holiday transition and what you expect for -- and what you've learned last quarter versus -- excuse me, last year heading into the March quarter? How should we be thinking about that margin sustainability also in early 2016?

ALAIN MONIE: If I look at the -- I would assume the comment is on the overall margin stability. And a lot of that comes from, it's a combination of both acquisitions as well as a better mix of value sales and more services. So it is a contribution, not only from the mobility side, but in the mobility side there is, because we have less distribution and more services, which really help our operating margins there, but also the addition of acquisitions whether it's in mobility such as ANOVO, but also the ones we just announced that are more in the value business. So those are improvements that are, I would call it, here to stay, given that they're structurally now included in our fabric.

OSTEN BERNARDEZ: Got it. But I'm sorry if I'm not making it clear. I guess my question was more specific towards the Verizon supply chain business and how in last year you had the higher rate of returns than expected. I would assume that there will be some returns obviously after this holiday season, and I understand that you have better terms today than you did before. But how should we be thinking about the potential sort of the seasonal impact from a sales and margin perspective, just...

ALAIN MONIE: Yes. Bill, you want to talk?

BILL HUMES: Yes. Hi, Osten, this is Bill. Yes. Overall, I mean, when you said supply chain, it's really actually the distribution business on that mobility side in the U.S. Last year, both Q3 and Q4 last year, we didn't see the returns yet coming in. And the profitability, we talked about last year was still pretty good, was roughly around the operating margin of 2%. Now, as we saw a significant amount of returns post year-end, that would have reduced that level of profitability.

Going into Q4, and also fixing into Q3, we've limited, one, the level of returns that we can, and will accept, as well as where the most returns came in, that business we did exit. So going forward, we shouldn't see the impact as significantly and as unanticipated as we did last year. So it's really -- we really have fixed the business or exited what could not be fixed to the level that we needed it to be. So going forward, it's much more attractive business, it just happens to be smaller.

OSTEN BERNARDEZ: Got it. That's it from me. Thanks.

OPERATOR: Thank you. (Operator Instructions). Our next question comes from the line of Keith Housum with Northcoast Research. Please proceed.

KEITH HOUSUM, ANALYST, NORTHCOAST RESEARCH: Good afternoon, gentlemen. Question for you on, I guess, the dynamics of some of the acquisitions are going on are in the splits. With HP splitting into two in November one, and Dell and EMC getting together. There's been a lot of talk that the channel being a big part of both of those enterprises going forward. As you guys think about the activity with both of those developments, how do you think it's going to impact the business going forward?

ALAIN MONIE: Yes. This is Alain. I'll let everyone else chime in, if you want to. On HP, in spite of the fact that there is an appearance -- apparently of a very big difference, we have been for many years really working with HP as two separate and two different divisions, both the enterprise side or the printing side. So, today, this change externally is probably not going to have a lot of impact directly into the way we have been working with them. There were separate different contracts, different go-to-market organizations. We had specific teams dedicated to all of these businesses.

As you can imagine, it's a very large diverse business and we had specific teams aligned with them. And in as much as they had a lot of work, I'm sure to do in splitting their organization, on our end, our organization was already well aligned with those two separate organizations. On the other hand, I think that, as part of their own strategy to grow their business independently now, the channel is going to be a more important piece than it was. And so I would see that more as an opportunity for us to even play a bigger role for HP.

As far as the Dell, EMC combination, although it's too early to tell what the real impact will be, we believe that this is going to create an opportunity for new products to be sold. And our strategic partnership with Dell is extremely solid, which we count on leveraging there. So without being able today to give you any precise potential impact, we only see potential positives here because of our partnership with Dell and the fact that by integrating those two it helps us offer an even stronger solution set based on their integration.

KEITH HOUSUM: Great. Thank you.

OPERATOR: Thank you. Our final question is a follow-up from the line of Brian Alexander with Raymond James. Please proceed.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: Okay. Just a few quick ones. One is, I assume neither of these acquisitions are in your fourth quarter revenue guidance since they haven't closed. And two is on the cost savings, I think it's $10 million in Q4, is that incremental or is that cumulative? And then I just have one more.

BILL HUMES: Yes. Hi, Brian, it's Bill. Overall, no, the acquisitions aren't in our fourth quarter forecast, we do expect to close them towards the end of the quarter. So they don't have a significant impact neither way. On the...

ALAIN MONIE: Savings.

BILL HUMES: On the cost -- on savings, we realized about $5 million in Q3 and expect $10 million savings in Q4, which would be especially at $40 million run rate then, so it's incrementally about $5 million on top of the $5 million realized in Q3, but cumulatively we should have $15 million for the 2015 year. And then beyond the full run rate or closer to it when we enter 2016.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: Okay. And then to the extent you get more involved in these return programs on the iPhone as Jim was asking about earlier, I assume that's a situation where you're not going to have any inventory or balance sheet risk. I assume that's really more of a services value proposition, or maybe just help me understand that better.

ALAIN MONIE: Yes. Most of our business in that -- and I'd say most because there are some cases where we do buy and sell and in our regeneration type of business, but most of that is done on a service, fee-for-service. And so, yes, you're correct that there is very little impact on our balance sheet.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: And then finally, Bill, you intimated earlier to a question that the cash conversion cycle should come down from where it's been. Could you just maybe give us -- maybe a range on where you think it should settle?

BILL HUMES: Yes. It's hard to say exactly where in the range, but we do expect year-over-year reduction, whether it's couple of days or whatever, that's definitely something we're targeting and shooting for. And then we expect a further, I'd say, into 2016, we'd expect to be able to strip a little bit more out as well.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: So just on a go forward basis, I'm not pinning you down to one quarter, but should we be thinking mid-20% is your target or high-20%, what's the right way to think about the range?

BILL HUMES: Yes, I mean, if you think about in the past, we've been -- we've previously in the kind of 22% to 26% range. Few of these quarters, most recently, we've been over. We're back in that range, and I'd hope to be towards the very end of that or lower range or even a different range. So we'll see as it all pulls -- kind of falls out and we realize it, but we have a significant focus on driving best practices across the globe. We're working on inventory procurement, working on other areas of working capital and working capital opportunity. So we are really driving that with intense focus. So we do expect some benefits and reductions. We're just not ready to say that the level of range, but we do expect improvements.

ALAIN MONIE: We are at 25 days, and we expect improvements both in Q4, and to some extent also in next year. So that gives you the starting point and improvements from there.

BRIAN ALEXANDER: Okay. Great job on profitability and cash flow this quarter. Thanks.

BILL HUMES: Thank you.

ALAIN MONIE: Thank you, Brian.

OPERATOR: Thank you. We have no further questions at this time. I would like to hand the floor back over to management for any closing remarks.

DAMON WRIGHT: Thank you, Gloria, and thank you all for participating with us today. And we look forward to the opportunity over the next couple of months to sit down with a number of you at upcoming conferences. Have a good evening.

OPERATOR: Thank you. This conclude today's teleconference. You may disconnect your lines at this time, and thank you for your participation.

urn:contentItem:5H8G-90V1-DXH2-64WN-00000-00Q3 2015 Kilroy Realty Corp Earnings Call - Final2015-10-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:19:43ZLexisNexis102915a5826411.711Q3 2015 Kilroy Realty Corp Earnings Call - Final

Corporate Participants

* Tyler Rose

Kilroy Realty Corp - EVP & CFO

* John Kilroy

Kilroy Realty Corp - Chairman of the Board, President & CEO

* Jeff Hawken

Kilroy Realty Corp - EVP & COO

* David Simon

Kilroy Realty Corp - EVP, Southern California

* Rob Paratte

Kilroy Realty Corp - EVP, Leasing & Business Development

* Mike Sanford

Kilroy Realty Corp - EVP, Northern California

Conference Call Participants

* John Kim

BMO Capital Markets - Analyst

* Craig Mailman

KeyBanc Capital Markets - Analyst

* Vance Edelson

Morgan Stanley - Analyst

* Michael Bilerman

Citigroup - Analyst

* Brendan Maiorana

Wells Fargo Securities - Analyst

* Nick Yulico

UBS - Analyst

* David Rodgers

Robert W. Baird - Analyst

* Jed Reagan

Green Street Advisors - Analyst

* Jamie Feldman

Bank of America/Merrill Lynch - Analyst

* Steve Sakwa

Evercore ISI - Analyst

* Ross Nussbaum

UBS - Analyst

Presentation

OPERATOR: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Q3 2015 Kilroy Realty Corp Earnings Conference Call. My name is Caroline and I'm your Event Manager for today. At this time, all participants are on listen-only mode. We will conduct a question-and-answer session towards the end of the conference. (Operator Instructions) As a reminder, the call is recorded for replay purposes.

And now, I'd like to turn the call over to Tyler Rose, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Please go ahead sir.

TYLER ROSE, EVP & CFO, KILROY REALTY CORP: Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us. On the call with me today are John Kilroy, Jeff Hawken, David Simon, Heidi Roth, Mike Sanford, Rob Paratte and Michelle Ngo. At the outset, I need to say that some of the information we will be discussing is forward-looking in nature. Please refer to our supplemental package for a statement regarding the forward-looking information in this call and in the supplemental.

This call is being telecast live on our website and will be available for replay for the next seven days both by phone and over the Internet. Our press release and supplemental packages have been filed on a Form 8-K with the SEC and both are also available on our new website. John will start the call with a review of the third quarter; Jeff will discuss conditions in our key markets; I'll finish up with financial highlights and a review of our updated 2015 earnings guidance that we provided in yesterday's release.

Then, we'll be happy to take your questions. John?

JOHN KILROY, CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD, PRESIDENT & CEO, KILROY REALTY CORP: Thank you, Tyler. Hello everyone and thank you for joining us today. Let me start by addressing the recent articles and questions related to the strength of the tech sector generally and the San Francisco market specifically. While we are always on the lookout for signs that the real estate market is changing, for both the good and the bad, we currently see nothing on the ground in our discussions with tenants and business leaders or in specific real estate statistics that suggests that the cycle has turned.

UCLA Anderson and The Economist are forecasting two more years of expansion. Revenue producing technology companies continue to grow and benefit from the proliferation of the internet and mobile devices and West Coast real estate markets continue to build strong momentum, with fundamentals improving in all of our submarkets including San Francisco.

Quarter-over-quarter, we saw demand increase for large blocks of space due to supply stayed limited and rental rates continue to rise. Sublease space fill in San Francisco and Silicon Valley had a 10-year high in absorption. In our discussions with Executives of large technology companies about their internal studies on head count, they note that San Francisco and Seattle remains the top markets in the US for attracting talent. We see this in recent reports on tech job openings, which remain robust.

San Francisco reported over 3,500 tech jobs to fill; Seattle reported almost 3,000 and Los Angeles reported more than 2,200 tech job openings. We also saw Google, Microsoft, Apple, Amazon and others recently report stronger than expected earnings. We don't want to sound Pollyannaish, we acknowledge that it's a risk to current economy and we are mindful of the importance of venture capital funding to the tech industry, particularly with the start-ups.

We just aren't seeing deterioration in the fundamentals. In fact, the level of demand both in Silicon Valley and San Francisco has never been stronger, as evidenced by the data. San Francisco has had 1.5 million square feet of net absorption so far this year, with another 500,000 square feet projected for the fourth quarter. There are currently 26 San Francisco requirements of over 100,000 square feet, up from 15, last quarter and only two spaces of that size are available.

Silicon Valley has already had one of its strongest absorption years with projections for a very strong fourth quarter and we're seeing demand increase in all of our markets. In San Francisco, demand increased from 7.8 million square feet in the second quarter to 9.2 million square feet in the third quarter, an 18% increased. In Silicon Valley, demand increased to 9.4 million square feet from 8.2 million square feet in the second quarter, a 15% increase.

Seattle increased about 25% to 30% third over second quarter. With a strong market conditions, we made solid progress during the quarter. We wrote newer renewing leases on 385,000 square feet of space in our stabilized portfolio, putting us just over 1 million square feet year-to-date. We are now 95.6% occupied and 97.2% leased. Rents in our third quarter leases were up 39% on a cash basis and 53% on a GAAP basis.

We also have approximately 400,000 square feet of letters of intent outstanding in our core portfolio. On an adjusted basis, we produced a year-over-year increase in cash same-store NOI of 5.4%. We delivered 100,000 square feet of office space to NeueHouse at our Columbia Square mixed-use project in Hollywood. We completed the acquisition of 100 Hooper Street, the last fully entitled shovel-ready development site in San Francisco for $78 million. We effectively settled all remaining outstanding issues with our surrounding neighbors regarding the development of our One Paseo mixed-use project in Del Mar and are moving ahead on entitlement and design.

We completed the sale of six non-strategic properties in San Diego for gross proceeds of $163 million. We completed the sale of $250 million of equity to help fund our current development program and we issued $400 million of 10-year bonds to replace maturing debt, and maintaining the strength of our balance sheet. We also continued to make progress on our development program. In addition to delivering the historic office space at Columbia Square last quarter to NeueHouse, we completed and delivered the first building at our Crossing/900 projects earlier this month. We expect to complete and deliver the second building in early November. The two building 339,000 square foot office property located in downtown Redwood City in the heart of Silicon Valley is fully leased to Box.

We commenced construction, just two months ago, on our Exchange at 16th project, our 700,000 square foot development project in Mission Bay. We are in negotiations and have significant interest from a variety of tenant prospects both tech and non-tech. Of the roughly 2 million square feet plus of interest for this facility, approximately 60% is non-tech. And I might add that the demand numbers I gave you on San Francisco don't reflect a shadow pipeline where we've signed NDAs with several people that represent millions of square feet beyond that nine-point-some-odd-million square feet of current demand. So we think things are shaping up very nicely for the Exchange.

So we anticipate and we're confident that The Exchange will be substantially leased well before completion of construction, which is not scheduled until the third quarter of 2017. And earlier this month, cash rent commenced on Phase 1 at our 350 Mission Street project, The 450,000 square foot SOMA office tower is fully leased to Salesforce. Tyler will discuss revenue recognition later in the call.

With regard to our near-term development pipeline, our four projects remained extremely well positioned for potential starts next year. First is, 100 Hooper Street. As we have previously discussed, we can start construction at any time, but we'll likely wait until we have executed a significant portion of the leasing on The Exchange or on Hooper itself before we break ground. Since acquiring the site three months ago, we are in early stage discussions with a handful of both tech and non-tech prospects, any one of which could take substantial space in or a majority of the project.

Second is One Paseo in Del Mar, our mixed-use development project that will bring much needed contemporary office, residential and retail space to the very affluent neighborhood of Del Mar. We made significant strides this year with our neighbors and community groups to settle all the issues and let's move forward on the approval process and we anticipate being able to start construction mid next year of one or more phases depending on market conditions.

Finally, the near-term pipeline includes the Academy in Hollywood and 333 Dexter in South Lake Union, both projects located in strong and vibrant markets. We expect to have final approvals on both projects by the end of the second quarter. Taken as a whole, these four projects represent a near-term development pipeline with a preliminary estimated investment of approximately $1.5 billion.

Looking further out, we continue to make progress on expanding and designing a world-class destination at the Flower Mart in San Francisco. We recently completed the acquisition of a 0.5 acre site to add to our development plans, Subject to final entitlements and market conditions, we expect to commence construction in approximately two years and estimate the total investment to be slightly over $1 billion, including land.

In total, our overall development pipeline acquired at a very attractive basis provides a tremendous opportunity to create value over the next several years. Each project is distinctly situated in highly desirable sub-markets that provide the infrastructure we seek, including public transportation, retail, residential and entertainment amenities, as well as communities that embrace historical or iconic elements.

Turning to dispositions, through the end of the third quarter, we completed the sale of 10 buildings encompassing more than 1 million square feet of space in a land site in Orange County for total gross proceeds of $335 million. That puts us at the high-end of our projected dispositions for the year. But with investors showing strong ongoing interest in acquiring commercial real estate and the continued disconnect between public and private valuations, we continue to look at additional opportunities to sell non-strategic assets and recycle the capital into higher value creating opportunities.

We are currently working on another relatively large disposition transaction that will likely close in the first quarter and expect to have more details to share on this front on our next call. More broadly, as I said earlier, the fundamentals across our markets remain strong. We believe the markets we operate in are uniquely attractive to growing companies given their access to talent, public transportation and cultural and lifestyle benefits that appeal to a generational force.

We are taking nothing for granted and are [sober] with regard to the cyclicality of our business. We've operated in West Coast markets for more than 65 years through multiple cycles. And our track record as a public company shows that we develop when it makes sense, we acquire when it makes sense and we just manage our core portfolio when that makes the most sense. We will continue to operate with this investment strategy. On the operational front, we remain focused on our top priorities of leasing, capturing in better rent growth, on-time and on-budget construction, and financial strength.

With that, I'll turn the call over to Jeff for a review of our markets. Jeff?

JEFF HAWKEN, EVP & COO, KILROY REALTY CORP: Thanks, John. Hello, everyone. Economic conditions across all of our markets remained strong. California continues to add jobs at a robust rate and forecasters now project the state's job and GDP growth will consistently outpace the US through at least 2017. A similar story is unfolding in the Greater Seattle area, where unemployment has now hit an eight-year low and job-creation continues at a rapid clip.

Let's take a look at the real estate fundamentals in each of our markets, starting with San Francisco. San Francisco Bay Area continues to outperform most other US markets with strong demand and a limited supply of large blocks of commercial space. Sublease space declined in the quarter to 1.2 million square feet or 1.6% of the market, down from 1.6 million square feet in June or 2.1% of the market. Class A direct vacancy remains effectively at 0% in the SOMA district and 8.4% in the South Financial district.

Silicon Valley had a very strong third quarter with over 1.6 million square feet of absorption. Tech expansion has driven Class A vacancy rates in the region, excluding San Jose down to 3.6%, the lowest in almost a decade. We are currently 98.6% leased in the Bay Area and our in-place rents for the region are approximately 32% below market. In greater Seattle, strong demand has pushed asking rents to their highest level in almost a decade. In our primary Seattle submarkets of Bellevue and South Lake Union, Class A direct vacancy rates are now at both 5.6%. In Downtown Bellevue, Salesforce recently announced it would double its workforce and triple the amount of its leased office space.

Our Seattle portfolio is currently 97.4% leased and our in-place rents are approximately 10% below market. In our San Diego markets, steady business expansion coupled with limited amounts of new commercial office space continue to drive rental rates higher. There have been 11 new Class A leasing transactions greater than 20,000 square feet in 2015, after only three in 2014. In our Del Mar and Sorrento Mesa submarkets, Class A direct vacancy rates are now 9.4% and 5.8% respectively.

Our San Diego portfolio is currently 97.4% leased. Our San Diego in place rents are approximately 7% above market. We are seeing strong rent growth in Los Angeles, particularly in markets attractive to creative services, entertainment like Santa Monica, West LA, Beverly Hills and Hollywood. In West LA, the Class A direct vacancy rate is 11.6% and in Hollywood it is 5.1%.

Across our Los Angeles portfolio, we are now 95.4% leased. Our in-place rents here are approximately 16% below market. Looking at our overall portfolio, we now estimate that our rents are roughly 15% below market. Remaining 2015 expirations total approximately 276,000 square feet with 200,000 square feet now expected to be vacated. This includes Qualcomm's recent announcement they would not be renewing their 68,000 square feet with us in Sorrento Mesa. That's an update on our markets. Now Tyler will cover our financial results in more detail. Tyler?

TYLER ROSE: Thanks, Jeff. FFO was $0.77 a share in the third quarter. We ended the quarter with stabilized occupancy at 95.6%, down from 96.7% at the end of the second quarter. As we previewed on earlier calls, our occupancy dipped in the third quarter due to lease rollovers in several of our markets. Most of this space has now been re-leased.

Same store NOI was up 5.4% on a cash basis and 3.6% on a GAAP basis in the third quarter, after adjusting for 2014 lease termination fee. We were active in the capital markets during the quarter. In July, we completed the registered direct placement of just under 3.8 million common shares for proceeds of approximately $250 million and in September, we sold $400 million of 10-year senior unsecured notes in a public offering at an annual interest rate of 4.375%.

The funds from these transactions were used to fund the $78 million acquisition of Hooper Street and the repayment of two maturing mortgages totaling $90 million. We will also pay off $325 million of maturing bonds next week and use the remaining proceeds to fund development spending. Taking all these transactions into account, we will have a $100 million of unrestricted cash after the payoff of the bond and full availability on our $600 million bank line, which is expandable to $900 million

Now let's discuss updated guidance for 2015. To begin, let me remind you that we approach our near-term performance forecasting with a high degree of caution. Given all the uncertainties in today's economy, our internal forecasting guidance reflect the information and market intelligence as we know it today and each and every shift in the economy, our market tenant demand, construction cost and new office supply going forward could have a meaningful impact on results in a way that's not currently reflected in our analysis. Projected revenue recognition days for new developments are subject to several factors that we can't control, including the timing of tenant occupancy.

With those caveats, our assumptions for the remainder of 2015 are as follows. As always, we don't forecast any potential acquisitions or acquisition-related expenses. We anticipate remaining 2015 development spending on our seven projects under construction to be approximately $150 million. On the development delivery front, as John mentioned, we delivered the first building at Crossing/900 in Redwood City in October and we expect to deliver the second building in November.

While we had anticipated that we would recognize revenue on our 350 Mission Street property in the fourth quarter, given tenant delays in completing TI work, we now anticipate revenue recognition to commence in phases starting in January with stabilization expected in the second quarter. The change of timing has no impact on cash rents as Salesforce began paying rent on about 20% of the building earlier this month.

Our core portfolio assumptions are follows. Given our continued strong same-store performance, we are increasing our projected 2015 GAAP same-store NOI growth to a range of 3.5% to 4% on an adjusted basis. We are lowering our projected year-end occupancy to approximately 94% driven by Qualcomm's decision not to renew 68,000 square feet in Sorrento Mesa.

We expect occupancy to be back up to approximately 95% by the end of the first quarter and we now project 2015 FAD payout ratio of approximately 70%. To sum up, last quarter, we provided 2015 FFO per share guidance of $3.30 to $3.40, increasing our mid-point $0.03 to $3.35. This quarter, given the stronger project revenues of roughly $0.04, partially offset by delayed revenue recognition totaling $0.015 of 350 Mission, we are again, increasing the midpoint of our 2015 FFO guidance by $0.03 to $3.38 per share and tightening our range to $3.36 to $3.40 per share. That's the latest news from KRC.

Now, we will be happy to take your questions. Operator?

Questions and Answers

We already have about two-thirds of that in the bag for early next year and I think we'll increase that substantially. It could be the number of multiples of that. TYLER ROSE: This is Tyler. On the comment on leverage neutral, as you know, our leverage is very low, debt to market cap is in the mid 20s; debt-to-total assets it's probably 30-odd; debt-to-EBITDA is now down to -- at the end of the year into the low mid-sixes. So we have that capacity as well.

JOHN KIM: John, on the large disposition that you referenced, can you provide any commentary on what market it's in and whether not it's a developed asset or an asset you acquired?

JOHN KILROY: I choose not to do that. We have a confidentiality agreement with these people that doesn't really allow us to talk about it. So I've got to honor that. But we signed purchases and sale agreement, they're just completing their due diligence and I'm very comfortable with the transaction.

JOHN KIM: So, the rental levels are increasing, you're getting higher releasing spreads, but the TI is still pretty high.

JEFF HAWKEN: Yes, I think, generally speaking again it's based on each particular space, but again, you're seeing really good spreads on the rents and I think tenant improvements concessions are certainly down in terms of free rent pretty much across our markets. So it's really just a function of tenant improvements.

JOHN KIM: Okay, and then my final question is on NeueHouse and if you can provide any commentary on how they are operating as far as their own occupancies and if you have any appetite to expand with them in other markets.

DAVID SIMON, EVP, SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, KILROY REALTY CORP: I could take that. So they are open and operating in Hollywood and they have a very deliberate pace on how the membership works there. Hitting or meeting their expectations and coming in and they had a huge lineup of potential membership prior to even openings. So the space is great. They're off and running to a great start in our Hollywood project.

JOHN KILROY: In terms of the other part of expanding into the other markets, they'd like to expand with us in other markets and we're going to look at each of those individually, see what makes sense.

JOHN KIM: Got it, thank you.

OPERATOR: Craig Mailman, KeyBanc.

JOHN KILROY: Well, again, we have a bunch of NDAs on that property with just about every tenant we deal with now the substance requires you to sign an NDA. So we can't really disclose who they are, but the tenants that we're working with and there are several of them. And it is our goal to make those transactions. And I think we will. I'm very comfortable we're going to make -- we can't make all of them because we don't have enough square footage. But I will say this, non-tech tenants take a lot longer than tech tenants to get deals done with.

CRAIG MAILMAN: I guess, but the way you are looking at tech credit these days, are you guys scrutinizing it more or less than six to 12 months ago.

JOHN KILROY: I think we're very thorough in scrutinizing tech credit six months ago and a year ago and two years ago. If you look at some of the tech tenants that were smaller, we had massive letters of credit. And we had great comfort that the buildings, because the buildings were designed by us for unknown tenants as supposed to design specifically for a singular tenants. So we felt very comfortable that we had assets that would perform well.

There was a pickup with the tenant and we had tremendous credit support. So our underwriting, I think, has been very thorough throughout this cycle. We have not done deals with some of the tenants that we thought didn't have great credit, where we had the opportunity and we will continue to show a lot of scrutiny with regard to our financial review of our customers, whether they are tech or non-tech.

CRAIG MAILMAN: That's helpful. Then, I guess as you guys walk the space these days, particularly on the tech-side, what does the utilization look like?

JOHN KILROY: They're just packed in. I mean, Rob, you want to comment, I mean you meet with all of our tech tenants and all of our tech prospects as well as non-tech on a regular basis?

ROB PARATTE, EVP, LEASING & BUSINESS DEVELOPMENT, KILROY REALTY CORP: Sure. Good morning, everybody. We do meet as John said, on a regular basis with all of our tenants as well as prospects and these are well established national and multinational companies and they have very deep real estate teams that do nothing but study headcount, and as John said earlier at The Exchange, with a couple of the tenants we're talking to, it's not going to be a quick decision, just the snap of a finger to take 0.5 million square feet as an example.

OPERATOR: Vance Edelson, Morgan Stanley.

VANCE EDELSON, ANALYST, MORGAN STANLEY: Great, thanks. So, John, you did a great job addressing the tech question upfront. JOHN KILROY: Well, I'm certainly not an expert on that and I will say this, we have tenants in our buildings like Capital One, which look exactly like a tech company that took two floors at 201, 3rd Street and there in San Francisco, looking like tech companies because they're funding tech companies. So you have the banks in it in a big way now and you have the VCs obviously in it in a big way historically and then you have some of the big tech entrepreneurs that are the household names that have made billions, that are funding other tech companies and going around the VCs. They are, in essence, being their own VC I suppose. So the funding sources seem to be increasing.

And I just want to point out something here because frankly, I'm a little frustrated with some of the articles that have been written by some of the people that are probably on this telephone call. I understand that we've had five years of terrific growth in San Francisco and Silicon Valley and four years or so in Seattle with the tech-sector. But there are other sectors that are growing tremendously. I wish I could tell you what I know, but I can't find one sector because we have NDAs (inaudible).

But I think that what we're seeing here is, it seems like there is some hiccups when Twitter said they're going to not proceed with 100,000 foot lease and lay-off 300 people or something or Zynga, a year ago when they have had their problems and it's a bad business model, I suppose for them. These are the natural hiccups that we're going to see. But if everybody and every single tech company have to be doing terrific for people to write positive articles, then by definition, you can't always have a positive article.

The reality is, I have never seen a market nor have the brokers that I talk to or the people I work with here that have long time been in San Francisco and Silicon Valley, never seen markets stronger than they are today; never seen demand greater than they are today; never seen a supply imbalance greater than it is today, on the positive side, meaning lack of supply.

There are two major things that are going on. There is a revolution in technology, if this was the Industrial Revolution, it'd 1900. Think about the disruption that's going on, I think Marc Andreessen, the famous VC investor said it very well several months ago, new technologies are devouring entire industries. It's happening at all different levels, Cyber Security, Medicine and Technology, which is in its infancy, Technology and Media, Active wear and wearable's, Fin-Tech meaning financial tech, which is in part to your issue about financing is that major financial institutions, banks and so forth are buying these start-up financial to entrepreneurs that are in the technology side, because they can't develop this creativity themselves.

That is exploding, in automobiles, driverless cars and in movies, in entertainment, in energy; almost every industry is transformed or will be by technology and we are in the early stages of it. And with that, we are going to have some volatility. I think the way I would characterize it is, we're going to have tremendous growth over the next several years and for many decades, but it will be punctuated at times with some volatility because we're not going to see every company or start-ups go to the moon. And you can tell that I'm frustrated, most of you know me for a long time, I have never seen such a disconnect with what's being written by some and what's going on the ground. And I care more about what's going on in the ground

VANCE EDELSON: And then just shifting gears for Tyler, the G&A line dipped a noticeable amount, anything unusual there? Or is that a decent run rate going forward?

So it doesn't have any impact on the bottom line of FFO. JOHN KILROY: I think to the first part of the question, I have never had more people come into this office that are foreign sources of capital as I have in the last six months, never. Not in the rest of my life up until that time. And I think if you apply those cap rates and those IRR projections to our buildings -- to most of our buildings which were rented at higher rents, you would have value substantially in excess of that. There is a wall of money trying to buy both foreigners and others in this city and elsewhere. And again, I've never seen it to this magnitude.

MICHAEL BILERMAN: And then, how do you balance and I recognize it is a balance, but raising equity at [66] if your belief is that the value of your assets is that dramatically above that selling equity in your Company, arguably at a big discount and taking that dilution, obviously you're using it to fund accretive development. MICHAEL BILERMAN: Yes

JOHN KILROY: Yes, I mean just take a look at it. We're building to roughly 8% -- going at plus or minus 8% going in ROCs. So I think that the use of the proceeds speaks for itself.

JOHN KILROY: Well, Michael look what's going on, the hedges play the techs and then the play the companies, the real estate companies that are public that do business with the techs. We all know what's going on. Hedge fund industry is out of control in my view. MICHAEL BILERMAN: As long as it is not ours, do you have any -- I mean you think about the affordability from a rental perspective residential side in San Francisco, clearly that's getting a lot of airtime in terms of people living [what's going on] at Oakland, right and Uber going over there and trying to attract employees. I mean, does it give you any concern at all in terms of the price of entry to attract talent and that talent being pushed out of San Francisco and that potentially affecting the residential market, affecting the office market.

JOHN KILROY: You know there are things called roads and ferries and BART and Caltrain and that's how people get to work. The lion's share of people that work at San Francisco don't live in San Francisco and the transportation and housing is a regional issue in just about every city in the world, certainly here in the Bay Area. You can't deliver enough houses in San Francisco over the next 10 years to satisfy the number of people that wanted to live here. It's always going to be expensive to live here.

But what you're seeing is a tremendous number of apartments being built in the city. You're seeing a tremendous number of apartments being built in Oakland. You're seeing them being built in other another areas and people will commute via the transportation systems. That's why we've been such an advocate over the last six years of projects that are near public transportation. These cities don't want cars. They want you to use public transportation and it's sort of a chicken and egg.

You have to have public outcries that we need better public transportation in order to get people to pay for the bonds and so forth that finances it. Here in San Francisco, they're talking about additional -- they've been acting on it. They got trans-bay terminal under construction; they've got the Central SoMa Subway that will connect BART and Caltrain that will start construction here shortly; they're talking about more BART tubes. Transportation always lags, but housing is generally going to be at the end of those transportation terminals. The city of San Francisco does not have the land area to build everything it needs to build.

So I'm not going to say that we're harder on people than we were before, because we've always been pretty hard on tenants.

BRENDAN MAIORANA: And Mike, maybe just, as you are looking at rent growth on a forward basis maybe over the next year or so, kind of what do you think -- what are kind of the best expectations of forward rent growth and how does that compare to maybe where it's been over the past year or two?

MIKE SANFORD: Yes, so historically we've been seeing double digit rent growth both in the Valley and San Francisco and if you look at what we've seen year-to-date, you're on pace for over 10%, again that 10% to 15% range in both markets.

As John said, we're more conservative as we project out and looking at rent growth when we underwrite. John talked about this for years and so from a cost per employee perspective, rents are actually down. There has been sort of a paradigm shift in how people are using space and they're using it more densely and we're providing the building the service in exiting and the like and the elevator so and so forth to support that density.

BRENDAN MAIORANA: Okay. That's great. And then just last one maybe for Jeff or Tyler. So you guys mentioned that year-end occupancy down to 94% because of Qualcomm. I think it was 94.5% last quarter. From third to fourth quarter, most of it is in San Diego. I think there is a 160,000 feet and a 130,000 feet of that's in San Diego and 30,000 feet of its in Seattle.
